title: Kylian Mbappe broken nose , the medical assessments and the pros and cons of protective masks
body_text:
â€œIt looked pretty nasty and itâ€™s not ideal â€” but itâ€™s not a disaster, is it?â€ says the former England and Newcastle striker Alan Shearer. â€œCrack on. Itâ€™s a broken nose, not a broken leg.â€
He is referring to the collision between Kylian Mbappe and Kevin Danso during Franceâ€™s 1-0 win over Austria in Dusseldorf on Monday. As Mbappe attempted to head the ball, his face crashed into Dansoâ€™s shoulder. Scans later revealed he had broken his nose.

â€œIt shouldnâ€™t keep him out from playing,â€ adds Shearer, a columnist for The Athletic. â€œA couple of rods straight up the nose â€” that would have brought a tear or two to his eyes â€” and then away you go again.â€
Shearer would know. He broke his nose twice within the space of eight weeks. The most painful was when he and former team-mate Rob Lee â€œsmashed into each otherâ€ during Newcastleâ€™s 3-2 win at Derby County in April 2002.
â€œI had a big hole in my nose,â€ he says. â€œIt was bleeding, sore, throbbing, a little bit wonky, but you soon get over it. Itâ€™s not as if youâ€™ve snapped your cruciate or broken your ankle.â€
This is true, though every situation is different. France manager Didier Deschamps was certainly not optimistic post-match, describing the injury as a â€œblack markâ€ on Franceâ€™s victory. At least Mbappe left a Dusseldorf hospital in the early hours of Tuesday morning reassured that he would not require surgery for the time being and a mask would be fitted to enable his return to play.
The French Football Federation has not confirmed whether he will be fit to play against the Netherlands on Friday in arguably Franceâ€™s toughest group game at Euro 2024. But what are the chances of his involvement and what are the consequences for the rest of the tournament?
The Athletic has spoken to nasal experts to find out more about the injury and likely recovery process â€” they did not all agree â€” as well as mask-making, and consulted former England internationals Shearer and Faye White to glean their experiences of how the injury and wearing a protective mask affected them.

The damage?
â€œThe nose is made up of several bony structures at the top of the nose,â€ explains Robin Youngs, a former consultant ear, nose and throat (ENT) surgeon at Gloucestershire Hospitals.
â€œThen there are other structures made out of cartilage â€” thatâ€™s the soft bit of the nose lower down â€” and then there is the nasal septum, a bit of cartilage and bone that separates the right from the left nostril that goes down the middle. All of those things can be damaged.â€

The nasal bones are attached to the bones of the face, called the maxilla. When the bones are fractured they are either â€˜displacedâ€™ or â€˜undisplacedâ€™. Fahmy-Fayez Fahmy, consultant ENT surgeon at Cambridge University Hospital, thinks Mbappeâ€™s injury is a displaced fracture to one side â€” a very common sporting injury, particularly in rugby.
â€œThe whole of the nasal pyramid, effectively his nasal bones, have shifted, almost like a wonky tent,â€ he explains. â€œItâ€™s a lucky injury because you can sustain much more serious injuries with a frontal impact.â€
Mbappe has not had surgery, which, according to Manuel Chamorro, head of maxillofacial surgery at the Quiron Ruber Juan Bravo hospital in Madrid, means the nose has been straightened. â€œIt will not remain displaced,â€ he says. There have been reports in France that the nose was reset by the teamâ€™s medical staff in the changing room immediately after the final whistle on Monday.
The bones are reset to their normal position by manipulation, a procedure that does not require surgery and does not interfere with the integrity of the nasal framework. â€œThe decision to operate is normally based on the cosmetic appearance of the nose,â€ says Youngs, who adds Mbappe may have opted against surgery to minimise any time on the sidelines.
Deschamps, the French head coach, has confirmed further examinations will take place in the next few days and has not ruled out Mbappe undergoing surgery in the future.
The swelling around Mbappeâ€™s nose may last for about seven to 10 days, according to Fahmy. Crucially, the nose needs some form of protection for a couple of weeks.

The return to play?
â€œIf he has to miss one game, I would understand,â€ says Shearer. â€œBut Iâ€™d be amazed if heâ€™s going to miss more than one.â€
The playerâ€™s view is not shared by all on the medical side.

In Chamorroâ€™s opinion, contact sport should be avoided. â€œAfter such a fracture, I would recommend at least a monthâ€™s recovery. In the acute phase, the bones have to be put in place and I would wait a while because the mucosal damage takes time (to heal). Itâ€™s difficult for him to play again in the European Championship, honestly.â€
But it is a major tournament. Mbappe is not going to wait around. That said, the French have to be sensible. Risking their star player for one game, albeit a difficult one against the Netherlands, having already endured a scare would be shortsighted.
Fahmy holds a different view from Chamorro.
â€œHe would need a few daysâ€™ rest,â€ Fahmy says. â€œItâ€™s unlikely heâ€™ll play the next game. Not only do you have a fractured nose but you have swelling around the nasal area and eyelids. It will be uncomfortable. I donâ€™t think they would risk him (against the Dutch), but he should be fit enough to play the following game (against Poland next Tuesday).
â€œHe will have a blocked nose. Itâ€™s not disastrous. Rugby players break their nose and they play two days later. Itâ€™s definitely not something that will hamper his chances to go all the way.â€
There have been many previous examples of footballers continuing to play with broken noses, but that does not stop it from weighing on their minds.
â€œThereâ€™s always a chance of getting an elbow or a flailing arm,â€ says Shearer. â€œEven if you mistime your header and it hits your face, you have to be aware of that.â€ The former striker notes that, although Mbappe sustained the injury by going up for a header, his aerial skill is not the strongest part of his game.
â€œHis game is all about balance, technique and running with the ball. Itâ€™ll be different for him. But I donâ€™t see it being a huge problem. Once youâ€™re out there, itâ€™s normal, you just forget about it and get on with it.â€

There are risks to consider, though.
â€œIt will almost certainly cause swelling and respiratory insufficiency,â€ says Chamorro. â€œI wouldnâ€™t play in a competition no matter how many masks he wears. Heâ€™s going to spend three months afterwards (attempting) to avoid problems.â€

Mbappe will have what Fahmy describes as a â€œblocked stuffy noseâ€ for at least the next two weeks. â€œIt will affect fitness levels, nasal breathing, the ability to deliver air to his lungs through the nose, but heâ€™s not going to be short of breath,â€ he says. â€œIf you play sport when you have a cold, you can breathe through your mouth. Itâ€™s not going to be detrimental to your competitive level.â€
Another concern with a recent broken nose is bleeding.
â€œIf he played again soon afterwards he might get a nosebleed during the game,â€ says Youngs. â€œBleeding from a broken nose can be quite severe and potentially a serious condition.â€
Loss of blood is never good. To stop the flow, surgery would be required to insert dressings into the nose â€” but Fahmy suggests bleeding happens in the first 24 hours and then is â€œextremely unlikelyâ€ to reoccur.
Shearer recalls his nose bleeding and taking a couple of days to settle down. â€œI just remember having to shove the odd bit of cotton wool up there to stop it,â€ he says. He did not have any problems with his breathing.
The masked striker?
There is a good track record of players successfully playing in masks. Mbappe will have one custom-made to protect the nose from further injury and hold the external part of the nose â€” the bit you can see â€” firmly in place.
â€œItâ€™s like a broken bone; you push it back to the correct position, but itâ€™s still not healed,â€ says Fahmy. â€œYou have a hairline fracture running across the nasal bones and this will be weak. A minor impact can potentially displace it again.
â€œIf I have a fracture and Iâ€™m just going to work, I donâ€™t need protection. But if Iâ€™m going to go and play contact sports, I will need protection for the next two weeks.â€
The mask will be moulded to the shape of his face, so it fits snugly. Nowadays, facial construction experts are more likely to use scans and 3D imaging to make the protective face-wear.

Manchester Cityâ€™s Josko Gvardiol, who broke his nose playing for former club RB Leipzig, wore a mask at the 2022 World Cup. The German club contacted Leipzigâ€™s university hospital, whose specialists designed the device especially for him.
The masks are usually made of a strong, light, thin material such as carbon fibre or thermoplastic and fit around the mid-face. For the first two to three days, Gvardiol initially had problems wearing the mask because it limited his vision and he had to adjust his breathing, but gradually he got used to it.
Shearer wore a small metal protective splint over his nose instead because he found a mask â€œuncomfortableâ€. White, another former England captain, has broken her nose three times and had to adjust to wearing a mask to protect a fractured cheekbone in the final of Euro 2009 against Germany.
She had flown back to London from Finland, where the womenâ€™s European Championship was being staged, to have her face scanned after undergoing surgery. While Whiteâ€™s and Mbappeâ€™s masks may vary in design, the concept remains the same.
â€œIt was a little bit too tight-fitting around my nose so I had to shave the mask the night before so it wouldnâ€™t dig in so much,â€ the former Arsenal defender tells The Athletic.
â€œI got to train in it, but your peripheral vision is affected slightly. Every now and then, I had to tilt my head down unnaturally to double-check the ball was where I thought it was. When you play without a mask, you donâ€™t have to do that, you know exactly where the ball is.â€
Tottenhamâ€™s Son Heung-min, who wore a mask having suffered a fracture around his eye socket in 2022, also expressed difficulty seeing the ball. Mbappe may not encounter this issue given his is a nasal injury, but it depends on how big the eye hole is in his mask.
The other consideration is the discomfort of wearing the mask simply because of the pain and swelling.
A mask would be a â€œsolutionâ€ but is not â€œoptimalâ€, according to Chamorro.

â€œIt is one thing if he wears it after a monthâ€™s recovery, but another if he wears it right now,â€ he explains. â€œIt hurts, it is inflamed, you breathe badly because it generates swelling of the mucous membrane. Mbappe bled and that means that the nasal mucosa has been broken by the fracture itself, by the displaced bones. The nose is blocked by the swelling itself and playing like this is complicated.
â€œTo put a mask on and go out to play on Fridayâ€¦ I donâ€™t see it. It is a very acute phase of the injury. The player is going to be very uncomfortable. I would wait a week, do a scan and see how the nose is. Letâ€™s not rule out having to check it in the operating theatre. I see it as very difficult to play in the short term.â€
From a playerâ€™s perspective, however, there will be impatience to return.
â€œYou have your mindset,â€ says White. â€œYou play through the pain because of how big the games are.â€
Of course, there is also the risk that, if Mbappe returns to play, he could break his nose again.
â€œIn competitive sport, itâ€™s very complicated,â€ adds Chamorro. â€œAny elbow or blow can multiply the problem. It looks like he was lucky and I wouldnâ€™t gamble with it.â€
Fahmy, however, has a different opinion. â€œIt can be fixed again. Rugby players do it all the time. Once it has healed, the bone is not weaker. For the first two weeks, you need protection but you can fracture it again. When someone has rhinoplasty, or a nose job, where you have actually interfered with the nasal framework and lose part of it, that makes your nose more vulnerable to injuries.
â€œBut a fractured nose, you fix it, it heals. You can fracture it again without anything disastrous happening.â€
That sounds more promising for the French. Mbappe has yet to score in a European Championship. Even if he is not risked in Leipzig later this week, the World Cup winner will be desperate to return and make a positive impression.
Real Madridâ€™s new striker, whether clad in a mask or not, remains a man on a mission in Germany.
